metadata.subject: Science
metadata.lesson_title: Recap & Practice — What Have We Learned?

objectives.primary_objective: Students recall what science means, how to ask questions, and how to observe using senses.
learning_outcomes: Review the meaning of science in their own words.
Ask and answer simple questions based on observation.
Use vocabulary words in short sentences.

word_list.definition: Learning about the world by observing and asking questions.
word_list.example_usage: Science helps us understand how things work.

word_list.definition: To look carefully to learn about something.
word_list.example_usage: We observe the weather every day.

word_list.definition: Something we ask to find information.
word_list.example_usage: He asked a question about rain.

word_list.definition: A way our body helps us notice things.
word_list.example_usage: We use our sense of hearing to listen to music.

word_list.definition: To tell what something looks, feels, or sounds like.

content_blocks.text: Let’s review what we’ve learned this week about science, asking questions, and observing things using our senses!
Say what science means in your own words. Try to use one or two of our new words: observe, question, or curious.

alternate_expressions: Science means learning by watching and asking why.
Science helps us discover new things.
Science is when we observe and explore the world.
ai_expression_coach.ai_prompt: Can you explain what science means in your own way?

ai_followup_feedback.positive_response: Beautiful! You explained science very well.
ai_followup_feedback.neutral_response: Good effort! Try adding how we observe or ask questions.
ai_followup_feedback.incorrect_response: Let’s fix that. Science means observing and asking to understand.

content_blocks.text: Now think of one question about something around you. Example: Why is the sky blue? How does the fan move?

alternate_expressions: How does water fall from clouds?
ai_expression_coach.ai_prompt: Can you ask your question in another way or make it shorter?

ai_followup_feedback.neutral_response: Try to make your question start with Why, How, or What.
ai_followup_feedback.incorrect_response: Let’s fix it together: start your question with Why or How.

content_blocks.text: Observation Practice! Close your eyes and listen. What sounds can you hear? Then open your eyes — name two things you can see.

alternate_expressions: I can hear a bell and I can see my notebook.
I notice music playing and a chair near me.
I observe light and sound around me.
ai_expression_coach.ai_prompt: Can you describe what you observed in a full sentence?

ai_followup_feedback.positive_response: Perfect! That’s how a scientist observes.
ai_followup_feedback.neutral_response: Good! Try using 'I can see' or 'I can hear' for clearer sentences.
ai_followup_feedback.incorrect_response: Let’s try again: start with 'I can see' or 'I can hear'.

content_blocks.text: Science means asking, observing, and describing. We use our senses and curiosity every day to learn new things!

star_rating_system.promotion_rule: Minimum 2 stars required to unlock next lesson.

strengths_analysis: Remembers and uses key words like 'observe' and 'question'.
weaknesses_analysis: Needs to connect observation and questioning more clearly.

for_two_star_students.growth_feedback: Well done! Try combining both a question and an observation next time to earn your 3rd star.
example_phrases_for_retry: I observe clouds and wonder why they move.
I see a plant and ask how it grows.

for_three_star_students.mastery_feedback: Excellent! You’ve mastered the big ideas of observation and curiosity — great recap!
